title: China's Covid-19 Restrictions Threatens Economic Recovery; First-quarter GDP figures painted relatively rosy picture, but data didn't capture full impact of Covid-19 restrictions
text:
More than two years after those initial lockdowns, "the pandemic has to be the biggest source of risk for China's growth this year," said Zhennan Li, chief China economist at AllianceBernstein.

The world's second-largest economy on Monday reported that gross domestic product increased 4.8% in the first three months of the year when compared with a year earlier, better than the previous quarter and above economists' lowered expectations. On a quarter-on-quarter basis, however, GDP growth slowed to 1.3%, down from the 1.6% increase in the previous quarter.

The data, however, doesn't fully capture the economic toll inflicted on the country by the lockdowns and other restrictions. The impact has been most severe in Shanghai, where 25 million people have been confined to their homes since late March, straining domestic logistics networks and dealing a blow to manufacturing, construction and service-sector activity.

Across the country, more than half of China's people have been impacted by Covid-19 restrictions as of mid-April, according to Gavekal Dragonomics, a research firm.

Though the GDP figures released Monday painted a relatively rosy picture for the first three months of the year, the numbers "didn't capture the full impact from Covid restrictions," says Mr. Li of AllianceBernstein.

That is partly because the data reported Monday largely predated the worst of the lockdowns, which began in Shanghai days before the end of the first quarter.

Now, as the crisis in Shanghai prompts more cities to adhere ever more stringently to Beijing's call for a zero-tolerance approach to the Omicron variant, the resulting supply-chain disruptions risk weighing further on China's robust export machine.

Widespread curbs on people's mobility also mean that any new stimulus measures, whether it be more liquidity in the financial system or more infrastructure spending, would be less effective in the near term.

"Beijing now appears to prioritize controlling the pandemic above all," said Tommy Wu, lead China economist at Oxford Economics. "That means local governments will likely focus on limiting infections and put aside concerns about the economy for now."

China's strict curbs to stamp out Covid-19 cases through mass testing and lockdowns, now on display to varying degrees in Shanghai, Guangzhou and other major industrial hubs, are only just starting to ripple through the economy and could potentially lead to an economic contraction on a quarterly basis in the second quarter, Mr. Wu said.

Economists from Nomura Holdings also see a rising risk of an economic pullback in the current April-to-June period compared with a year earlier.

Sporadic lockdowns across China over the past two years have already inflicted plenty of pain on the country's small businesses, in particular those in human contact-reliant industries such as the restaurant and tourism businesses, and look set to deliver another blow this year.

Sings of stress are also rising in China's labor market. The country's headline measure of joblessness, the so-called surveyed urban unemployment rate, climbed 0.3 percentage points to a nearly two-year high of 5.8% in March, breaching the government's targeted cap of 5.5% and nearing the 5.9% level last seen in May 2020, when China was just emerging from the initial outbreak in Wuhan.

Consumer spending, smothered since the start of the pandemic, is only expected to worsen as employers cut salaries and lay off workers. Retail sales, a key gauge of consumer spending, contracted more sharply in March than economists had feared, Monday's data showed.

Car sales will likely be significantly weaker in April than in March, with no growth expected for the full year, Cui Dongshu, secretary-general of the China Passenger Car Association, said Monday—a result of both weak consumer demand and disruptions to the auto-supply chain, he said.

Another potential casualty of widespread lockdowns is the export sector, a pillar of the Chinese economy that propelled the country's rebound from the pandemic.

Coming into the year, economists had already predicted export growth to slow after two years of outperformance.

Now, deepening supply-chain woes that prevent raw materials, inputs and labor from reaching factories and that keep finished products from reaching customers could mean that exports see no growth at all this month for the first time in nearly two years, Nomura economists have said. Chinese exports rose 15% in March compared with a year earlier.

Manufacturers including Tesla Inc. and Pegatron Corp., a supplier to Apple Inc., have halted production due to a shortage of components—though Tesla is among companies aiming to resume production this week.

Global shipping giant AP Moeller-Maersk A/S last week halted booking of refrigerated containers into Shanghai amid worsening bottlenecks caused by Covid-19 restrictions. Rigid pandemic testing rules and lengthy quarantines imposed on truckers have sharply reduced road freight capacity.

French bank Natixis SA has warned that supply-chain disruptions may deepen if more cities in the Yangtze River Delta, the industrial hub in and around Shanghai that accounts for 37% of China's total exports, impose similar restrictions to contain the pandemic.

As the economic picture worsens, Chinese officials have been tepid in their efforts to respond with stimulus.

China's central bank on Friday took the relatively modest step of reducing the amount of reserves banks must keep on hand in a bid to spur lending, though it disappointed expectations by keeping benchmark lending rates unchanged.

And higher prices for commodities such as iron ore and coal, as well as the prospect of interest-rate increases by the U.S. Federal Reserve in the coming months, threaten to further constrain options for central bankers in Beijing.

The biggest uncertainty, however, is when the country might ease up on its strict Covid-19 restrictions.

While authorities in Shanghai over the weekend pledged to help hundreds of companies resume production, other economic readings indicate that a return to a prepandemic environment remains far away, says Mr. Li of AllianceBernstein.

After Monday's data release, investment bank ING said it would likely further reduce its full-year GDP growth forecast from the current level of 4.6%—already well below the government's official target of about 5.5%—as more cities enter lockdown and China's central bank remains on the sidelines.

"Economic easing alone will be unable to offset the brutal effects of zero-tolerance lockdowns," Société Générale SA economists told clients in a recent note.
